content.question: The crystal structure of <math alttext="N a B r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is represented in the diagram above. Which statement correctly compares crystalline <math alttext="N a B r, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaBr</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to molten <math alttext="N a B r, liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaBr</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in terms of electrical conductivity?

choices.label: Crystalline <math alttext="N a B r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> contains no freely moving electrons that could conduct an electrical current, whereas electrons can flow freely in molten <math alttext="N a B r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is a good conductor of electricity.

Crystalline <math alttext="N a B r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and molten <math alttext="N a B r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> both contain ions that are held in fixed positions due to strong electrostatic attractions among the ions, making neither a good electrical conductor.

Crystalline <math alttext="N a B r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and molten <math alttext="N a B r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> both contain <math alttext="N a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms that transfer electrons to <math alttext="B r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms in a chemical reaction, thus allowing them both to be good conductors of electricity.

Crystalline <math alttext="N a B r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> contains no freely moving electrons to conduct electricity, but molten <math alttext="N a B r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is composed of freely moving <math alttext="N a with a positive one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B r with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions, which allows it to be a good conductor of electricity.

content.answer: Crystalline <math alttext="N a B r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> contains no freely moving electrons to conduct electricity, but molten <math alttext="N a B r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is composed of freely moving <math alttext="N a with a positive one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B r with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions, which allows it to be a good conductor of electricity.
